reviewText:
This is a difficult game to write about, but a few hours after playing it, I was left with several thoughts and feelings still floating around about what I’ve experienced. There’s a lot to process and possibly more than I think I’ll be able to get to here. I’ll be interested in replaying it and seeing where things stand from there, but for now this is what I’ve taken away from the game.

I heard good things about The Beginner’s Guide but not any details about what it was. At first I assumed it was a video game about being a rogue leftover part of a game in the middle of being made (The Magic Circle, I think) so as it turned out I knew even less than I thought about the game. It’s by Davey Wreden who made The Stanley Parable, a fantastic game which my brother introduced me to the demo of by insisting it was entirely different to the game itself. It was and the game is something fantastic to experience. This is a little along those lines as far as using the mechanics of a video game to tell a story.

The game stars one speaking character; Davey Wreden. He narrates the games which make up The Beginner’s Guide, acting as a kind of documentary of the works of a person called Coda. Coda’s a character whose personality and backstory is only provided by the commentary of Davey and the designs you walk through. I guess in a way you are the third character as the audience member walking through Coda’s world, curated by Davey.

To start off with, you’re wandering a Counter Strike map designed by Coda and right away there are things wrong with it, only visible once you start moving within the world. I knew a few people who tinkered with CS back in the day and it places this designer firmly in the era of people modding games that I know of. The errors look like they could be due to a first-timer learning what they’re doing but Davey tells us of recurring themes in the work of Coda. There are floating boxes, strange cubes and dead ends. It’s alienating and within or without the fiction it’s entirely on purpose to set the tone. We are not a person in the world, we’re a witness to a game being designed.

Once you have had a bit of a search and heard what Davey has to say, we skip ahead in time to the next project of Coda’s. It’s a space game with a non-working gun and an actual maze. Again, it’s something an amateur or an artist may have made and Davey has his own insights. The look of the levels are oddly charming in the same way that I find using the old graphics as to see how the original looked back in the day. There’s a moment where you die and Davey talks about Coda’s intent simply be that you die, only he experienced a bug which he replicates. You’re elevated into the air and can see the maze, the ship, all without a ceiling and the edges of the game world. There are sharp corners on the background and space itself is just a box you’re in. This is important, this change of perspective.

The narrative of The Beginner’s Guide is presented through the game’s mechanics, but on several levels. One of the next games is one where you play a character who can only move backwards through a level. This section is something which I could imagine standing on its own easily enough and has messages unique to the game as well as to the greater narrative. It reminded me a little of Passage which was a game asking whether you want freedom with loneliness or companionship with restriction. There was no right answer in that game. This one the restriction’s a little more linear and you switch between the ability to see what’s ahead or the ability to move without seeing to navigate. Again, this is important. All of it is. There are puzzles, but not many, this is more of a journey than anything else, but a ‘walking game’ which uses the minimal mechanics of the game to its’ advantage. In games like Dear Esther, you would be in awe of a heavily detailed world but at a loss of what exactly to do between chunks of narration. Here, the worlds are small and bite-sized, the worlds can be as small as a single room or massive and awe-inspiring.

Davey talks of the grander designs being experimented with and the meaning behind it all, as well as his experiences with Coda in real life. His interpretation of things like the series of small prison games, the domesticity of one game. There are recurring styles presented and some aspects evolve which reflects Coda’s growth as a person. His voice is only really experienced by little floating circles in one level and the dialogue options in a handful of games. Otherwise we’ve got the mechanics and Davey’s accounts as all you have to go on.

It’s fascinating to see and for ninety minutes as a documentary, fake or otherwise, it makes for a great use of the medium. The games themselves are fairly small and definite works in progress, but there’s something which has inspired the narrator and hearing his analysis of it helps drive us through. And this is where we get to the spoilers.

I don't know how this community is with spoilers, so I'm going to link to my site where the rest of the information is. There are a couple of flips in the narrative where it made me think deeply about one thing, then turned it round and made it all new again, all in a really short game. It's impressive and sticks with you. As I said, this all goes to spoilers. I hope you don't mind being shielded from them by me linking to my site here.

http://fakedtales.com/2015/10/15/the-beginners-guide-review/

reviewText:
Wow, just wow! What an amazing experience.

The beginners guide hit me hard. I've seen such a tragic story told in such a creative way. Coda is a game developer. The story is told through narration over every game he has made. Link's between his games and his life are made by the narrator. The narrators just tells the story so incredibly well and it had me hooked the whole way through. I can't go into too many details about the story due to spoilers but I loved it.

There's not really a whole lot to the beginners guide aside from the storytelling. Gameplay wise there isn't really anything apart from a walking simulator. But if your looking for a game solely for the story, like me, then the beginners guide is definitely for you.

The biggest issue with the beginners guide is the game is very short taking only around 1.5 hours to complete. But I feel this length is perfect. The story is told without rushing and any longer and I would have gotten bored.

Honestly I had no idea what I was expecting when I went into the beginners guide, but i'm so glad I purchased it. It's an incredible experience that will probably go down to me as being the best storytelling in a video game.

Obviously this game isn't for everyone. If your looking for an actionpacked game with lot's of gameplay then stay well clear of this.

If your happy with a game solely based on the story then go for it. To know what it is that makes the beginners guide just so good you'd have to experience it for yourself. I also believe for the amount of content offered £6.99 is a very reasonable price.

TheIronicGamers rating system
Don't ever buy this game.
Maybe consider it on a sale.
An average game.
A good game that should definitely be considered.
A must play!

While playing this game I wanted to write a review. I wanted you to know how this game spoke to me like no other game has ever done. I wanted to talk to you about my crippling depression and social anxiety. I wanted to tell you that identify with Coda.

But I can't.

For I am not Coda, I am Davey.

See this is the conundrum I face, If I hit the post review" button I am vile as Davey. I am seeking validation for my review
date: for my emotions. If people mark this review as helpful then my experience was not in vain. If I don't hit the button and simply close my tab I will be Coda. I will simply leave because I did not create my artistic work for anyone but myself
recommended: this is an outlet for my own creativity.\n\nBut I am not creative
hoursPlayed: I am not Coda. I am Davey and I hate myself."

reviewText:
After reading and hearing the glowing reviews I went into this game knowing it was a walking sim but expecting it to make up for it with some sort of very moving experience.

I certainly don't regret giving the game two hours my life to play it, and its not a bad game, obviously by all the glowing reviews out there. But it is certainly not worth 10$, probably not with 5$, maybe 2.50$, and I would probably recommend it if it were free.

I also want anyone going into this game to know that they might not have some sort of moving experience from it. The tropes and ideas it displays are all things any mature person has probably already encountered, and hopefully worked thru, displayed in a somewhat interesting way and new way. The sort-of underlying meanings and morals of the story are nothing new from your after school specials, just communicated differently.

---That's pretty much it for the main review but I do have my own interpretation as to whether one might get something special out of the game, so if that interests you read on.---

It seems to me the game indulges two sorta psyches.
If introversion and extroversion were laid out on a scale of 1-10 (since very few are complete introverts of extroverts)
With the lower spectrum being introversion and the higher spectrum being extroversion, the game caters to those who land on the outer edges of the scale.
So if you are a 1-3 introvert, like have legitimate difficulties interacting with people,
or a 8-10 extrovert, can't stand to not interact with people,
then I think you might have a deep experience with this game.
However if you are someone more so in the middle, like I feel myself to be, then there's not much for you in this game.

At least that's my interpretation.

reviewText:
Not really sure how to rate this one, as it's so different to anything else out there, perhaps I was expecting more from what I had seen of the gaming journo's reviews, and that led me to feeling a little bit underwhelmed by the end of it. I bought this on the basis that I really enjoyed The Stanley Parable, and saw a number of positive reviews.

It takes about an hour and a half to complete, and there isn't so much a game to play, but more a message to listen to, and it is in that whether you will enjoy it or take something away from it.  I would assume if you were more interested in human psychology, that it would prove to be a more interesting and worthwhile experience, but to give some balance to the review system I have to vote negatively as it didn't do it for me.

I guess it made me realise that the bits I most enjoyed about The Stanley Parable were the puzzles and the humour, which this lacks, although it's worth pointing out that this game was neither intended to be humorous or a puzzle game.

reviewText: This is an intense experience. It's a slow build and you must do it one sitting, that's not too much to ask as it only took me 90 minutes, but once it's done and finished you will be thinking about. It's an insidious journey through several layers deep of metaphor, one that just may make you cry.

reviewText: Wonderful in it's own special way, but bound to make some people disappointed. If you're looking for a fun game then don't bother, as it essentially lacks any game mechanics. It's quite short, meaning that the $10 asking price will not be worth it to many people. It also is very different from The Stanley Parable, and in fact it is very far from comedic, so fans of that might wind up disappointed as well.\n\nIt's a game that is difficult to explain without revealing some aspects of it and spoiling the whole thing, and it's best to go in totally blind. Blind faith is hard to sell, however, so if you're not willing to take a risk don't bother. It appeals to a niche audience that finds the medium of video games capible of being captivating and telling good stories without being a traditional game
date: and this particular story heavily benifits from having some limited interactivity. If that sounds pretentious or uninteresting then stay far, far away. Others, however, might find something that resonates with them, as I and several others have.\n\nIt's an ambitious game, but it's also very small and personal. It finds a balance, and it's beautiful. It might even be the best walking simulator" game to date
recommended: although that might not be fair because it's so different than any of those games that came before it.\n\nIn short

reviewText:
Do you like movies that spur endless internet discussions about their meaning? Then this game is for you.
(Please note the game wouldn't launch for me. I had to check the Steam forums and add launch parametres -novid -window -noborder to get it running.)

Let me start with the bottom line.
Is this game suitable for me?
Don't expect anything like The Stanley Parable, it's nothing like it.
This game isn't meant to be fun or enjoyable, it's rather supposed to make you think and feel. I'll let you decide if that's for you.
In terms of gameplay, this is very much a walking simulator. As the Steam store description says, it has no play mechanics, no goals or objectives. It is basically a guided tour. You walk around, look and listen, and click on stuff.
90-120 minutes gameplay, and no replay value.
It touches on themes of creativity, friendship, depression, anxiety, obsession, dependency, and projection. If it clicks with you, it will keep you thinking for a long time. It will remind you of people you know, maybe yourself. Remind you of situations you've lived.
I said earlier that it's nothing like The Stanley Parable. But inevitably, people will compare the two. They both are games about games" and they both feature walking around listening to narration. And in a way
date: the two are related. You can't help it - the same person is behind both.\n\nThe fiction of The Beginner's Guide (TBG) is that it's a guided tour by the developer
recommended: Davey Wreden. "Davey" (I use the quotes to denote the in-game Davey Wreden) narrates directly to us
hoursPlayed: the players
voteText: as he takes us through a compilation of small games made by a friend of his nicknamed "Coda". "Davey" says he compiled and released these games
helpfulPercent: in the form of TBG
votesHelpful: in order to encourage Coda to start making games again after he stopped
votesTotal: and to help him out of a depression.\n\n"Davey" clearly admires Coda's work
votesFunny: pointing out all sorts of ideas
commentsCount: patterns and themes in Coda's games
column16: and wondering at the thoughts and feelings that gave birth to them.\nThrough the tour
column17:
we get to know Coda and "Davey" better.

It's difficult to say much more about TBG without spoiling anything. What I've written above will have to be enough for you to decide if you want it.

Now I'll continue with my opinions on the game with major
column18:
complete spoilers.

SPOILERS FOLLOW.


No
column19: seriously
column20: there's major spoilers after this. If you're at all interested in TBG
column21:
don't read any further.

Are you sure?
Okay
column22: I'll continue now.\n\nReally
column23: really sure? No going back after this. I just want to be certain you know what you're getting yourself into.\nAlright
column24: here we go.\n\nTBG really is about The Stanley Parable. Rather
column25: it's about Davey Wreden's conflicted feelings after the huge success of TSP. On the one hand he felt a sort of disconnection from his creation because it was in the hands of so many people who saw their own meanings in it
column26: and on the other hand he craved every bit of admiration that came his way. "Coda" and TBG's version of "Davey" are two sides of the real-life Davey Wreden
column27:
and TBG's "Davey" is also an avatar of the masses.

Wreden details his post-TSP feelings in this blog post:
http://www.galactic-cafe.com/2014/02/game-of-the-year/

But what I also liked about TBG is that it also has a much broader interpretation. Several in fact.

"Davey" fawns over Coda's games and finds all kinds of meaningful
column29: emotional themes in his works. But they're really nothing but a bunch of unoriginal
column30: unfinished games. "Davey" projects his own anxieties and depression onto Coda
column31: becoming dependent. This shows between the lines in his narration
column32: and then is practically blared at us by the end. One of the game's poor points - Wreden abandons all subtlety and spoonfeeds us at the end of the game.\n\nSo it's about overanalytical fans who see meaning that is not there
column33: and ascribe their own emotions to an artist's work. "Stop putting lampposts in my games" was the most chilling line in the game.\n\nTBG is also about perspective in relationships. This is apparent in The Tower chapter
column35: making it clear that he does not consider him a friend
column37: and that "Davey" seems to think this is all about himself. This comes as a shock because "Davey" makes it seem like he and Coda are good friends
column38: throughout the games.\n\nOn top of that
column39: TBG is about how we sometimes go about helping people in all the wrong ways
column40: because we make assumptions and act selfishly while thinking we are being altruistic. It's about how we put emotional lampposts in peoples' lives.\n\nTBG may be heavy-handed
column41: but I feel that's a result of the weight of Wreden's frustration that he felt compelled to portray and lay bare.\nAnd in a contradiction to itself
column42: TBG will make you assign your own meaning to it. It's inevitable.\n\nYeah
column43: I'd say I recommend this. It's food for thought
column44: and it's an admirable portrait of a creator."

reviewText:
Short, undeveloped axiom focussing on things which should've been absolutely clear to people anyways. Slow paced and disappointment in character development do make the title quite fitting as you could interpret it as ''existentialism and introspection for dummies''. It's interesting and it makes you long to know what is behind the next door but every time it just leaves a bitter taste because it could have been so much more and with a little more thought it surely could have blown some minds (including mine) but it just feels so shallow and ultimately even kind of boring.

The two characters involved (Coda and Davey) feel relatable but the development just isn't there to make them feel like real people you can actually root for or against. It's kind of interesting while the game lasts but I just feel like another 1.5 hours where more depth and better pacing (though the strange pace does feel kinda cool) was implimented could have made this more complete. Just like this review would've been even better if I didn't just repeat the same two points but actually added something more to it instead of just making it seem that way by being constructive the second time around.


But you can still buy it so you can brag to your friends about the esoteric meaning you've found in this, I mean surely they'll respect you for it no matter what because it's an interpretation of ''art'' which makes you seem ridiculously deep to all of the other attention♥♥♥♥♥s.

Free this game would be a 5.5/10, for the price at which I bought it; 2/10 unfortunately. Would not recommend but if you can pick it up for -90% you could definitely do worse for that money.

reviewText: I...I broke down crying twice while playing this game.  The last time I shed a tear over a game was the ending of The Last of Us, and that was only a mild wetting of the eyes.  I imagine that there are players who won't connect with this game.  They have lead lives that have taken them down different paths and don't identify with either of the two charecters in this game, but if you have ever felt like a failure in life or if you have worried about if it is possible to make a real change in your behavior, then you might understand and empathize with what this game is saying.  Is that a recommendation? That this game can make you feel like ♥♥♥♥? I don't really know, but it's enough to make me give it a thumbs up.  The game is a 2 hour short story about creativity, connecting with others, and depression with basically no player agency.  If that sounds like something you want to experience then this game delivers.

reviewText:
It was my birthday a day ago. I had some money to spend on games, so I look onto my wishlist, grasping my digital forty dollars in my hand.
Two games, Killing Floor 2 and The Beginner's Guide. A real contrast, if anything.
I download the games, yeah, cool, and I hover over the button to play this game. For some reason I stop myself.

Do I know what I'm getting into?

Do I?

I booted it up, played it for a bit, and faintly struggled to put it down after about 4 levels, as I was also intent on playing KF2. Played that awhile, real nice game. But that's not what I'm here for.
A day passes and I sit myself down to play Guide once more, I'd actually felt like I needed to play it, to grasp it, to know what happens.

And... well. Now I've finished it.
I'm not sure on what to think about this game, it's a tale that comes once in a blue moon.

It left me feeling empty, alone, depressed, lonely, somber.
But, ...it gave me something else.

Find it for yourself. Find it in the game.
You'll know once you're there. Trust me.

reviewText:
So... I really wanted to like this game, even as a serious thing. I felt as if I could relate with the game's themes to some degree. But... I don't know, I didn't have some emotional revelation or connection or anything. It was interesting, but... I don't know, just something about it all rubs me the wrong way.

Maybe it's the price point? Games can't be judged by their play time, especially because you can get so much with so little. Unfortunately I didn't really feel as if I got anything, except overcharged and disappointed. :/ On the bright side, I did discover the Source engine apparently causes me to get motion sick? Yay?

reviewText: It really makes you think about some deep and heavy stuff. Would definitely recommend playing it all in one go, preferably by yourself, taking your time to absorb the dialogue and environments. It's as effective at getting into your head as The Stanley Parabe was, but takes you on a completely different kind of emotional rollercoaster. Be prepared for some serious soul-searching.\n\nIf you hate walking simulators" on principle
date: you probably won't enjoy this game. But if you want a gripping and thought-provoking narrative that effectively makes use of its medium
recommended: they don't come much richer than this."

Very outstanding.

reviewText:
At first, I thought it was going to be funny and all like The Stanley Parable was, but what it really was was a perspective of someone who genuinely thought he took something from someone he truly cared about by going through games the person made and showing them to the outside world.

!!!SPOILERS DOWN BELOW, VIEW AT YOUR OWN DISCRETION!!!


The game opens up with a narrator (not the one from The Stanley Parable) talking about a guy, Coda, who created games but never completed them and just left them to die. The first map Coda made was loaded up for me to walk around and observe- a very small Counter Strike desert map with some floating crates and odd things like that. From there, The Narrator goes on to show you the rest of Coda's games that he made in the order that he made them, showing the months and years they were made between loading screens. Some games required to be modified so one can actually get somewhere instead of being stuck forever, and I'm just going to skip to the last game that Code made that The Narrator showcased.

In the last map, Coda blamed The Narrator for what happened to him and how he tried to help" by showing all of his games to His friends and how they genuinely showed fascination at his work. Coda just didn't want him to interfere with his personal work and at the end of the map
date: which is IMPOSSIBLE to beat without either having to modify it or just have a lot of time on your hands (scratch that
recommended: it really is impossible to beat unless you have hax).\n\nSo in short
hoursPlayed: Coda blamed The Narrator for all that has happened to him and has stopped making games since
voteText: and He is genuinely sorry for whatever he did to destroy his privacy. It slowly delved more into sadness as more delicate topics were touched upon that weren't supposed to be rummaged through and nobody knows why Coda puts the same things into each game (if you play the game

reviewText:
After coming hot off the heels of The Stanley Parable, I was very excited to try this game out.  Unfortunately, it seems that my expectations for the game overhyped me and gave me a very different idea of what this game is really about.

This game is a story.  It's not really a game in any traditional sense. It's an aparently true story about the developer of the game and his friend, and the relationship they had, and the games that they made.  When I say this isn't really a game, I mean that the only real mechanics of the game are walking around and hitting button promps every now and then.  While you do these things, the game's narration plays in the background and adapts to your actions.  Some of the 'levels' of the game are actually pretty intresting, and I have to admit, the ending of the game got me.  However, this game can be completed in like 2 hours with very little replay value.  It's more like a library of levels, or like reading through the letters of two pen pals.

I would recomend this game only if the premise of this game interests you and if it's on sale.  I would say this is a better game then other walking simulators like Dear Esther, but not an amazing game overall.  I don't regret buying it, but this game is not what I expected and not really advertised well (to be fair it would be very hard to advertise a game like this).  Honestly as I'm writing this review I think I'm convincing myself more and more that I enjoyed the game, but I'm sticking to my inital impressions.

reviewText: The Beginner's Guide is a marvel of a game. Unlike the whimsical and ridiculous tone of the Stanley Parable, this game has a much more dark and personal storyline. I would go so much as to call it a journey. Digging into the mind of a game developer struggling to comprehend why a set of sporadic games were made made me realize just how powerful games can convey messages and meaning. I always knew that games leave emotional and personal marks on people after their first playthrough, but this was something else. Despite the small amount of content in the game and the lack of replayability, the story and the narration pack a punch from beginning to end, and anyone who appreciates the ideology of games or any sort of narrative journey should give this a try. Davey Wreden, you've manage to make me laugh my ♥♥♥ off and be on the brink of tears in your games, and I personally hope to see more from you in the future. There's a Coda for all of us somewhere Davey...I hope your friend returns to you.\n\n9/10 Would find the Lamppost again.

reviewText:
This... story...?
This... philosophy...?
This... point of view...?
This... game...?

Whatever this is, it is definitely something. Something that brought me to tears and inner revelations of many different kinds. It is a venture into something that you know/understand and don't know/understand at the same time.

Don't research anything else about this game. Buy it and play it for yourself, actually feel the game and reflect with it.

I NEVER buy games that take me less than 2 hours to beat. Ever.

But I'm buying this game for friends... and I know for a FACT that I'm going to be playing it again...

And probably again...
And again...
And again...

That's how great, sad, evolved, emotionally charged and emotionally drained this game made me feel. And I'm definitely going to venture into it more times as I go through my personal journey of life.

Thanks, Davey. This was and is a masterpiece.

reviewText:
You will laugh, you will cry, and that is okay. This is an experience, and truly a masterpiece in its own way.

There isn't a way to truly describe how this game will make you feel. Everyone is different, which is one of the story's themes ironically. At least that's how I interpereted it. If you get this game (and I whole-heartedly reccommend you do) please write down what you thought of it, have a friend play it, share your thoughts and experiences.

The atmosphere is superb, I was completely invested whilst playing, and while it was short for what it was, it never seemed to overstay its welcome. Although I must say at times, you really wish it would end, but not in a bad way. The tone gets a bit spooky, but don't worry, there is nothing actually scary. The atmosphere is just so good that you think there is! It's difficult to describe with words. which is why you should experience this gem yourself.

For its short playtime, I would definitely reccommend you wait for a sale however. Spooky Halloween sale is coming up, no doubt about it, so pick it up then.

reviewText:
You will laugh, you will cry, and that is okay. This is an experience, and truly a masterpiece in its own way.

There isn't a way to truly describe how this game will make you feel. Everyone is different, which is one of the story's themes ironically. At least that's how I interpereted it. If you get this game (and I whole-heartedly reccommend you do) please write down what you thought of it, have a friend play it, share your thoughts and experiences.

The atmosphere is superb, I was completely invested whilst playing, and while it was short for what it was, it never seemed to overstay its welcome. Although I must say at times, you really wish it would end, but not in a bad way. The tone gets a bit spooky, but don't worry, there is nothing actually scary. The atmosphere is just so good that you think there is! It's difficult to describe with words. which is why you should experience this gem yourself.

For its short playtime, I would definitely reccommend you wait for a sale however. Spooky Halloween sale is coming up, no doubt about it, so pick it up then.

reviewText: As a huge fan of The Stanley Parable, I was really excited to play this game. Sadly, it did not live up to expectations. I understood that this would be a mainly narrative experience and not feature much in the way of gameplay. but the narrative did not live up to what I was hoping for. It was an EXTREMELY short game, and there is no replayability. If this game is ever £1 then maybe it's worth it but you should consider it as renting a movie and for me this was not worth £5.59. I see what the dev was trying to accomplish but I don't think it was fully achieved. I wish I could speak more positively of this because I love the idea of exploring the gaming medium as art but this did not live up to expectations.

reviewText: I absolutely recommend The Beginner's Guide for anyone who develops games, is heavily interested in meta games, or just enjoyed the developer's previous game The Stanley Parable.  The game really soars as a short, deep and complex story that truly communicates and delivers on both the needs of the player and the intent of the game.  Well worth the money.

reviewText: Where The Stanley Parable was a dynamic and living converstion about the relationship between authorial intent and user agency, The Beginner's Guide proves a more linear narrative experience. Through iteration and narration, you'll eventually be allowed to observe and interpret the relationship between those that create and those who consume. Decide for yourself the virtues of the creative process and whether or not they can exist in a vacuum. Everybody will walk away with different interpretations, but this is a must play.

reviewText:
The Beginner's Guide is a powerful narrative. I don't think it's fair to discuss any element of it before playing through it in its entirety, but I want to convince people to purchase and play it with an open mind.

It's about an hour and a half long, and it's not your average game. It's a journey through creative works narrated by someone who has a deeply personal and important story to tell.

Think less of this as a game, and more as an experience. And please, play it.

reviewText: The Beginner's Guide is an unique experience. It's game that make you think of the psyche of people, and the way some people judge others based off things they do. In short, it's a psychological game that can be interesting to people who like games that don't tell a story in the traditional way. reviewText:
Do NOT think of this game as a game just like the Stanley Parable, do not think of this game as an adventurous, full of action first-person shooter of any sorts, simply put; do not think of this game as your average today game. Think of it as an interactive movie.

Just put that foremost, all I can say is that I'm almost speechless and there's still a bunch of questions going through my head at this point, I've literally finished the game just 10 minutes ago. I feel like this game reaches out to the depressed, anxious and isolated out there. Some of the messages left behind to me are the epitome of such a person experiencing the above.

The game is not for everyone, some may experience little to no feelings from such an experience, but for creative individuals this game is for you.

reviewText:
This game, no matter what you read or have seen of it before you actually play it, is nothing like that.

There are a lot of things going through my head after just wrapping up my playthrough of it, and needless to say, I feel that is the point. Not to reveal a fault in the two individuals' reationship mentioned in the game, not to publicize one's work and make $9.99 per copy from it, but to incite some sort of feeling, or multiple feelings, for those who come across this game.

I feel dirty, as if I had just paid money to experience the trauma, confusion, and loneliness of another human being. At one point I felt so submerged, as if I were the one troubling myself, and that I wasn't actually listening to a narrative. There are very relatable feelings throughout this story, ones that made my gut twist and left an unsettling taste in my mouth.

But don't get me wrong, I do not intend to make this sound negative. It is a very sad game about a very heart-wrenching experience between two friends.

Part of me is hopeful though, for the creator of this game. I hope he is able to make contact with the other individual and make amends. I am hopeful that he does not make the same mistakes that he did. I hope this reaches the other individul and that he sees that people are playing his games, and that they are giving it feedback. And mostly, I hope this review was helpful to whoever decides to read it. If you want to really feel by cause of a game, this is the one for you.

I think I need to go think about my life now...

reviewText:
A remarkable, strange and successful piece of narrative that uses games as form and subject.  I don't want to give too much away because it's better experienced than told, but this is a narrated anthology of short first-person games, narrated by Davey Wreden, who tells us that these are games created by a friend of his who is only referred to as Coda.

Closer to being an installation piece than a traditional game, this is nonetheless an immersive and fascinating experience that dwells on psychology, loneliness, unreliability, and the assumptions we make about others.  I can't think of the last time I enjoyed a game this short this much.

You'll finish this fast, but it will stay with you long after you do.  Don't get it if you're looking for a traditional first person game, be it shoot em up or puzzle.  There is a question being asked and answered here, but not by any traditional game mechanic.  If tis doesn't turn you off as a prospect, I can strongly recommed this game.

reviewText: It's late (12:30AM), and I've just finished The Beginner's Guide. What an..interesting experience. Definitely thought-provoking. I would argue life-changing. If you want a game that MIGHT leave you with something new (maybe a thought, an experience, a new perspective), I would make the leap. Don't worry about price (as I see that being the main reason I didn't buy this on launch), just go for it if you have the money to spend. I hope those that take my advice are met with an extremely pleasant and thought-provoking surprise.

reviewText: Short, interesting story driven walking simulator by the guy who made the Stanley Parable. The story's the only reason to play this game, it's more like a slightly interactive movie more than anything else. The tone of the story tends to blur the line between non-fiction and fiction and that's left a lot of people confused, but I think the creator left everything open-ended to prompt discussion. If you're expecting a Choose your Own Adventure game like Stanley Parable, you'll be pretty disappointed, the game is linear all the way to the end. I'd still recommend it for people who are interested in storytelling, non-standard game design/ standard game design, and topics such as depression, social anxiety, etc.\n\nNot really re-playable, unfortunately, but a fun and sometimes emotional trip.

reviewText:
This is the story of a man named Coda. Coda worked for himself in a big building where he was a game programmer and developer. Coda's job was simple: he sat at his desk in his room, and he pushed buttons on a keyboard. Ideas came to him through a monitor on his desk, telling him what buttons to push, how long to push them, and in what order. This is what Coda did every day of every month and every year, and although others might have considered it soul-rending, Coda relished every moment that the ideas came in, as though he had been made exactly for this job.

And Coda was happy.

And then one day, something very peculiar happened. Something that would forever change Coda. Something he would never quite forget.

Aside from the fitting Stanley Parable joke, this game really does speak for any artist who struggle with depression as well as the negative impacts of game developement (or rather just anything artistic in general) it can have on one's life. I recommend you getting this if you want to want observe the nature of how one struggles through it all. Otherwise I wouldn't because it's basicallly another freaking walking simulator.

reviewText:
Where to begin, where to begin... If only I had a guide for where to begin to describe this game.
I watched my friend play this game the other day, and saw him sit, riveted to his seat, as he stared blankly at this oh so simple game. As he pulled off his headphones, he simply shook his head and told me to get the game.
After it finished downloading, I sat down and began. It started out as a simple game, with Davey yet again weaving his subtle gaming magic into the dialogue.
Little could I have known how deeply into my very soul these threads were being woven.
The game took but a mere 84 minutes to complete, looking at all the content held within.
But the game took a toll on my poor, suceptible heart. As I followed in my friend's path, and removed my headphones, I sat, weeping, in my chair. The Beginner's Guide brought into questioning every friendship, relationship, and familiial tie I have ever known, and shattered me to my core.
On the simple topic of mechanics, it is a simple puzzle game, and by simple I mean it in the most literal sense of the word. You're truly playing this game for the experience, similar to playing the Stanley parable.
Davey remains one of my favorite game designers, ever since his beautiful work on the Stanley Parable, and this game just goes to show that it's the simple things in life that hit us the hardest.

P.S. Davey, I would like an apology for making me cry for a solid ten-twenty minutes.

reviewText: It's definitely NOTHING like The Stanley Parable, but I 100% recommend this game. It's not about gameplay and it's not about mechanics. This game is about thinking. reviewText:
Summary (TL;DR)
I never thought I would enjoy a game about uncompleted games.
As a student in game design, this is a great tool for me to tear apart and study. I've learned a lot simply from playing.
The story drew me in, I wanted to know much more about Coda and his games. I wanted to know why he made his games, what the inspiration was behind them, why the narrator/developer had such an interest in Coda's games.

The story takes a dark turn, and after completing the game I wanted to know the legitimacy of the story.
I went in thinking this was based on a true story, and was excited in the beginning as this was the first Interactive Documentary" that I'd ever heard of. It was exciting to play something that was familiar
date: but different in large ways.\n\nIf you are a Game Design student
recommended:
or just someone looking for a game with a great story this worth getting.

Pros    Great Narration
Captivating story
Great graphics
Very thought provoking
Minimal use of music was great and set the tone
A great combination of gaming and documentary
Neutral Points    I question the legitimacy of the game.
Tasks can get very repetitive.
Cons    Parts of the game can seem slow
Rating9/10"

reviewText: The Beginner's Guide is an example of a classic sophomore slump. It's highly disappointing as it was made by the same guy as the brilliant The Stanley Parable. It's a walking simulator consisting of a string of seemingly randomly made levels made with the Source engine. There's a narrator that explains the fictional significance for the design of each level. There's a “twist” at the end that is completely unearned. Essentially, what this software does is tells a story and then at the end tells the audience that he lied about the details of the story and we're supposed to be shocked by the reveal. The story made absolutely no connection with me at all. It was a waste of 2 hours of my life. The genius of The Stanley Parable is that expertly deconstructs common mechanics of video games and challenges the player to reflect on why games are designed the way they are and why we, as the players, act the way we do in the game world. The Beginner's Guide is completely devoid of any of this. The Beginner's Guide seems like the developer had a bunch of unfinished attempts at creating game levels, cobbled them together and put some bullsh.t narration over it and called it a day. The developer has demonstrated that they are very talented and I hope this abortion was just a fluke.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you're looking for a game to live up to the astounding creativity of The Stanley Parable, look elsewhere.  Unfortunately, this game is one of the most overrated titles I have played in recent memory.

The narrative is muddled and unfocused.  The level design is mostly unimaginative, notwithstanding a few highlights.  The emotional response that so many people write about was just a blip on the radar for me, which surprised me.  I really didn't connect with this game much at all.  There are few moments in game that truly resonated with me, but otherwise I was left wanting.

This game feels like an alpha version of something with a lot of potential.  If the designers had put in some more time and fleshed out certain concepts a little more, I think we could have been left with another classic.  As it stands, all we have an overpriced, undercooked 80 minute game.

reviewText:
What a strange little thing this is. I'd hesitate to call it a game; it's really more a short story told in a somewhat unconventional fashion.

I enjoyed it. It's very different from The Stanley Parable. There's nothing to laugh at here, and only one path through the story, but it's well constructed and has some really strange ideas that stuck with me long after I'd finished it.

If you're interested in games as a narrative mechanism, absolutely give this a go.

It has low hardware requirements and played very nicely on an old Mac - but there was a very annoying bug where the mouse was completely unresponsive in game until I went through the settings and changed all the mouse options a little.

reviewText:
What kind of indie arthouse ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t was that.

I've played weird games before. Undertale, The Stanely Parable, Imscared. When a game tries to give me a message, a message about games in of itself, I listen. I watch. I pay attention.

But this... if whoever programmed all these games is a real person, then it's really disrespectful of Davey to go against his friend's wishes. Either way, this shouldn't have been a game that costs money. It should've been distrubuted freely, to spread the message. It feels like Davey released this simply because he knew people would buy it since he wrote The Stanely Parable.

Whatever the case, I can't recommend The Beginner's Guide. It may be odd, it may be moving, but it's not worth it.

reviewText: I can't recommend this enough as a shining example of genius narrative writing. Mr. Wreden has an amazing talent for crafting worlds and scenarios that get the player invested. I played this about a week before launch and was so upset I couldn't talk about what I had experienced, because it left me in awe and made me want to hug the nearest person I could find. The story is fascinating, unexpected, and leaves you with a lot to think about by the end. It's one of the best narratives I've ever been a part of, if not the best.\n\nIf any of what you've seen interests you, please, like with The Stanley Parable, don't spoil the content for yourself. You're not at all going to get the experience from watching someone else play it, and that's not an exaggeration. Please, if you have the money and are interested, just trust that you'll enjoy what you get and dive right in.

reviewText:
First off, if you're expecting The Stanley Parable with it's branching choices and endings and humor, stand in one spot for a second.This game is NOT the Stanley Parable, but is it good? Oh yeah. Is it worth the price? I definitely thought so.

Should you watch Let's Plays or read reviews that talk about the story before buying? Probably (and highly reccomendedly) don't.

I'm gonna talk as spoiler-free as possible, so here I go:

The Beginner's Guide is a one-shot game; it's a lot smaller than The Stanley Parable, and there isn't that much to explore in the game in terms of ending and whatnot. The narration and plot isn't going to change depending on what you do. However, this game takes you on a ride. An emotional ride, and if you are in any way familiar with the subject matter it presents then it's going to strike home and make you think about things you might not have even consciously thought before.

However, this might not be the 'game' for everybody.

Like the description states, there are no traditional mechanics, no goal, and no objectives. Much like Dear Esther, i's more akin to a walking simulator (though much more successfully executed) than anything, and you might get two or a few more plays from it if you're going to examine it throughly but otherwise once is gonna be it.

Despite that, for the price I just can't argue with the experiance I got from it; it's just as much as I would pay for a movie ticket and took much more than I normally would from most regular ol' movies.

Worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
I struggled to come to a conclusion on whether or not I would recommend this game. It's a shame that Steam doesn't allow a neutral option.

On the one hand, this is a beautiful game. There are some interesting and thought-provoking environments. Even after the game had ended I spent a while to take it all in; to go over everything I had witnessed and experienced. The game is intelligent and I applaud it for that.

However, the trailer makes you think that you will have more control over what happens. That you, yourself will be trailing through this random person's documents and games; trying to form your own opinions and conclusions on what they are like, based upon the things you see. However, this isn't how it really is at all and for that it feels like the game is slightly mis-sold.

The issue with the narration style is that it doesn't allow you to form your own ideas, or at least, not as much as I'd like. No sooner had my mind began to wonder about Coda and his feelings, the narrator would tell you what he thought Coda had been feeling. I felt this stifled my thoughts. I wanted more time to explore, to delve into the games and psychoanalyze it all.

I feel that the game didn't expand as much as it could have. There was a lot of potential but it fell a little short and for that it feels a bit underwhelming.

reviewText: This one really didn't do it for me.  The Stanley Parable was brilliantly written, played with impossible space in amusing ways, and had a lot to say about nonlinear interactive fiction.  This... is a collection of cries for help.  The interactivity is minimal, and the narration defeats any attempt to take this seriously as art.  It's like watching a movie with audio commentary the first time through.  There's some twists in the narrative, but I did not enjoy this.  Melodramatic and minimalistic, this really didn't feel like it gained anything by being a game.  I'm a strong proponent for storytelling in games, for the medium to be used artistically.  This didn't move me at all.  It's depressing, but not in the intended sense of sharing the creator's existential dread.  If there's any truth to this story, the people involved have my sympathy, to be certain.  It's a sad story, but not one that needed to be presented as a videogame.  And certainly not one worth the purchase price.
voteText: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I went into this game completely blind, with no idea as to what to expect and feel like you should too, so I'm going to keep this review intentionally vague.

It's not for everyone and some people won't like it, that's perfectly fine - but if you're a fan of interactive narrated experiences, then purchase this now. The Beginner's Guide is an incredibly unique game with a ton of emotional input which spoke to me on a very personal level. The Steam description says it lasts an hour and a half, but it took me two and I would like to replay it once more in future, it's all very linear but interesting enough that you may want to give it a second look. The game is narrated by Davey Wreden, the creator, and he does an absolute wonderful job of his role, the script he's reading is great and the emotion in his voice comes across as genuine.

The themes explored in this game were very relatable to me and because of that, I really connected with this experience and just overall, absolutely loved it. Stick with it to the end and pay off is extremely satisfying.

helpfulPercent: and draw

reviewText: This is a thoroughly interesting walking sim. You wander around a lot of small, linear levels, ostensibly all standalone indie games. Some of these are visually striking, and there are also some well-placed cuts that remind me a little of Thirty Flights of Loving. What ties it together is the narration, which is set up like a developer commentary track. The dialog gets a little too on-the-nose toward the end, which kind of undermines what had up till then been a fairly poignant story, but it's still entertaining. Worth a playthrough if you're into art games. Oh, and the music is very, very good.

reviewText:
tl;dr - This is a game that will make you not only question how games should be made, but what you think you know about ulterior motives.

Note to self:
Don't play The Beginner's Guide when you're sleep deprived and right before class.

OKAY, SPOILER TIME. DON'T READ IF YOU WANT TO PLAY THIS GAME!

So, much like The Stanley Parable, The Beginner's Guide is a though-provoking game with no clear end that challenges you mentally. It's narrated not by the same person who narrated The Stanley Parable, rather the creator of that game. The narrator, Davey, takes you through the games made by his friend Coda and discusses his thoughts on the reasons behind Coda's games from what he could discern. This goes on for about an hour and fifteen minutes. the last 20 or so minutes is Davey contradicting literally everything he's spent telling you in the first hour+, and having a slight psychological meltdown, admitting his innermost thoughts, fears, hopes, and desires before ultimately leaving the player a few minutes or so before the game ends.

I loved everything about this game. While no, it does not have a clear end-point, it's amazing and makes you think. 10/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Hm.. Where do I start?
I was recommended this game by a friend, who said it was sad and all(I'm a sucker for sad games) so I decided to go and buy this. Knowing it was one the creator behind The Stanley Parable I suspected some quite... weird, or depressing themed stuff even to begin with. So I sat down and played this in one go and, well.. what can I say? I really recommend this game to everyone actually. It leaves you thinking about how you treat other people, but also yourself, and how you should handle harsh times in life.  I think this game is about the combination between inspriation and motivation to create, and so I really related to it. At one point this game really crept deep inside of me and I felt sick because of what you were suppoused to do. And I think that's a success.

I expected a bit more from it though, I thought it was more of a game with actual characters more than a commentary -- but it was still great.

reviewText:
It is very hard to review these kinds of games because there is, admittedly, very little to measure them on. Is it a walking simulator? Quite possibly. Is it for everyone? Absolutely not. That's the wonderful thing about The Beginner's Guide. It's different, and it is definitely a game that you would see more as an experience than something you really participate in.

In the terms of the narration it showcases some really neat things in it's presentation, some of which can really open your mind to new ideas. The narration is easy to follow and it's something you will want to listen to. It's engaging and deep. For a product that openly advertises itself as not including standard game mechanics or goals, it is just that. That is the only expectation you should go in with.

It's absolutely a game I will need to ponder for a little while, and that's a good thing, as a creative person, I find value in what this game explores. Not everyone will, and that's okay.

Similar to everyone else's reviews, I don't want to spoil anything. However, in likeness to other people's reviews, I will say that if you are a game developer, or even a creative person, a musician, an artist, a filmmaker, or anyone who makes content for people to consume in any way, this will likely appeal more to you. This isn't something I would be putting onto a 'game of the year' list, it's simply an experience worth experiencing. Go into it with an open mind. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
‘The Beginner's Guide’ is a remarkable, deceptive and touchily deep creation that achieves ultra-realism with minimalist graphics and game-play. This is the consummate showcase of the mediums capabilities; it’s the unquestionable proof that videogames are capable of delivering substantial thought provoking experiences.

Not only that, but it acts to demonstrate the power of human creativity, and the effects imposed on those fine minds that reluctantly persist with their craft; across all mediums of creation.

‘The Beginner’s Guide’ deserves to be analysed for years to come.

reviewText:
A short and brilliant introspection on creativity and social interaction.

In The Beginner's Guide, you get to follow the story and train of thought of a man who desperately tries to help a friend, only to realise that not all who wander are lost, and that hell is paved with good intentions.

I've always been a huge fan of story telling in video games, and The Beginner's Guide has just set itself as a monument in the genre: It's profound, intimate, wise, and truthful. You share the narrator's every word and thought, following closely on his confidence, anger, disbelief, and eventually acceptance of what he did. A truly magnificent essay on a mistake we all made at some point in our life, and that will hit home for any creator out there.

It's short, and do not expect any form of gameplay besides walking and listening. Is the story even true? Probably not, but The Beginner's Guide will still teach you one of the most beautiful lessons there is: Learn to let go.

reviewText:
This American Life:  The Video Game.

Some say that it's the ultimate defence for the 'Games as Art' argument, as the narration and design attempts to fortify and demonstrate an example of this philosophy, but this player believes it's more than that.

It's a documention of a man's passion and 'life's work' up to now.  It's a declaration by developers who feel that their work should be a means of expression and not mere entertainment for others.  It's a rebuttal to the many who believe that gameplay trumps other aspects of a game.

Walking Simulator?  Well no.  Dear Esther is more of a walking simulator.  In this game the narrator is talking to you instead of just talking.  And this is nothing like The Stanley Parable where the narrator openly mocks you and challenges you.  It is far less interactive than The Stanley Parable, but probably just as immersive.

People who played The Stanley Parable may or may not like this game as it is less interactive.  However, people who love ramblings and insight on the radio as well as The Stanley Parable will probably enjoy this game, like I did.

If you want to consider what it means to develop a 'game', and whether a game minus gameplay can still be a purposeful and meaningful experience, install this and contemplate for a time.

...  I do miss Kevan Brighting's voice though.

EDIT:  The Ending demonstrates a reason why creators (be it writers, artists, game developers) who are friends can just so easily get into a fight over personal space, distrubition rights (for each other's work) and so forth.  It's...  A call for help...  Players must reach the ending if they wish to truly make sense of what this 'game' is.

...  And whether you agree if it should have been released at all.

reviewText: WOW. That was a roller coaster. The idea of little snippits of someones work is very interesting, and to have an awesome narrator going over it was SUPER COOL. reviewText:
tl;dr - This is a game that will make you not only question how games should be made, but what you think you know about ulterior motives.

Note to self:
Don't play The Beginner's Guide when you're sleep deprived and right before class.

OKAY, SPOILER TIME. DON'T READ IF YOU WANT TO PLAY THIS GAME!

So, much like The Stanley Parable, The Beginner's Guide is a though-provoking game with no clear end that challenges you mentally. It's narrated not by the same person who narrated The Stanley Parable, rather the creator of that game. The narrator, Davey, takes you through the games made by his friend Coda and discusses his thoughts on the reasons behind Coda's games from what he could discern. This goes on for about an hour and fifteen minutes. the last 20 or so minutes is Davey contradicting literally everything he's spent telling you in the first hour+, and having a slight psychological meltdown, admitting his innermost thoughts, fears, hopes, and desires before ultimately leaving the player a few minutes or so before the game ends.

I loved everything about this game. While no, it does not have a clear end-point, it's amazing and makes you think. 10/10

reviewText:
Hm.. Where do I start?
I was recommended this game by a friend, who said it was sad and all(I'm a sucker for sad games) so I decided to go and buy this. Knowing it was one the creator behind The Stanley Parable I suspected some quite... weird, or depressing themed stuff even to begin with. So I sat down and played this in one go and, well.. what can I say? I really recommend this game to everyone actually. It leaves you thinking about how you treat other people, but also yourself, and how you should handle harsh times in life.  I think this game is about the combination between inspriation and motivation to create, and so I really related to it. At one point this game really crept deep inside of me and I felt sick because of what you were suppoused to do. And I think that's a success.

I expected a bit more from it though, I thought it was more of a game with actual characters more than a commentary -- but it was still great.

reviewText:
Okay, at the first you don't think it would be fun to play random games by a random person one by one.
It's okay to feel boring and to want to stop playing the game. Just keep playing a little bit more. And then you'll know that you just started the game. The actual game. Things will start to begin horribly wrong.

Maybe, some of you will cry.
Maybe, some of you will be terrified.
Some of you, no, all of you will get depressed.

It's really more than that you might expect to see from a game that just seems to be showing random games by a random person. Rather it's... really, seriously, much more than that.

And you might want to see what's that. Personally, I think you 'must' want to see.

reviewText: This game, at it's core, is a truly impressive narrative that sucks you in and keeps you at the edge of your seat for the entire time - and even afterwards as you try to digest what you just experienced. It's perfectly paced, has great foreshadowing that will give you suspicions and theories throughout the game while keeping the ending a surprise. The characters are easy to relate to and are very strong and believable, to the point that everyone seems to argue whether Coda is real or not!\n\nIf you're a lover of stories and narratives, this game is 1000% for you - I can't remember the last time a game or movie moved me like this game did. While certainly the game is short - honestly I'd much rather play a well placed short game that invoked such strong emotions than a long game with filler to pad out the time and distract from the story.

reviewText:
The Beginner's Guide is an experience. A good or bad one, that is for the player to decide. The message that the author encoded may not be that special, but what you decode is quite meaningful, regardless of the experience being good or bad. It still moves you.

Personally, I found the game too self-involved for my taste. But then again, the game was self-reflexive enough to counter the sense of entitlement it conveys. The sense of entitlement obviously had a purpose, and I found the whole interaction interesting and thought of it as a novel way of existence for the designer outside his creative space, but it was definitely blatant.

There's not much out there that could be considered similar to The Beginner's Guide, so even for that, this game deserves to be played.

reviewText:
This game is..... well, this isn't a game you absolutely have to play at some point, but if you ever get the chance to, you probably should.

I don't believe it matters what kinds of games you like with this one, and i don't even think it matters what kind of person you are. This is something rather special and thought-provoking, potentially even tear-jerking if you're anything like me.

But the less said about it the better. It's definitely something you should experience as uninformed as possible.



P.S. Davey Wreden, you're probably never going to read this, but on the very slim off-chance that this somehow reaches you:

Thank you. And whatever you do, the most important thing is that it's what feels right to you, and that you do it with the best intentions. Even if you never made a game again, you have my fullest respect.

reviewText: Let me preface this by saying that in the year that I've had Steam I've never been compelled to write a review about a game. The fact that I am doing so now is surprising to me.\n\nIf you let it this game will take you for an emotional ride. Other reviews I've read say that the emotional aspect of the game is heavy handed or forced and that the narrator sounded like he was reading from a script. If you want to enjoy it just let yourself be swept along by it. If you're reading a mystery novel do you skip to the end to find out who did it? No, that would spoil the experience. Bring that same mindset with you when you play The Beginner's Guide and you'll get your money's worth.

reviewText: I was absolutely captivated by The Beginner's Guide. I had no idea what it was about when I got into it, but I loved the Stanley Parable so much that I looked forward to seeing a new project from the creator. This one unravels slowly, but does so to build up very good dramatic tension. It was a very intimate message about the struggles of creation, game development, and a relationship (I won't go into detail there). If you have ever had experience trying to make games or if you just like more experimental projects, this is one you must experience. It kept me thinking long after I finished.

reviewText:
This is one of the first reviews but most in-depth one I have ever written about a game and I think that says something in itself. I've not even created a review for Dota 2 yet and I have about 3.3k hours on it at this point in time.

This game is good. I'll give it that. It's got depth. However, there's something within this game that allows itself to be distanced from other games; to transcend from the term game for a moment and adopt the role, message. This game is a message and it's physical. A physical representation of a message is the basis of this game. This game doesn't just put you in the shoes of the fictional character the developer wants you to be but instead makes you him. Himself. You see through his eyes. Your process through his mind. You walk in his footsteps. Neither one of the many aspects of this game leaves more to be desired because it is undeniably complete. Complete in the most ironic sense and you will know why when you've played this game. I'll give you a tiny little spoiler here (too insignificant to spoil the game). The developers provides you with his own personal e-mail to drop him any messages about your perspectives or even mere thoughts about the game. Whether he did this for an intensified dramatic effect, I do not know but I got a strong feeling at the end of the game that it wasn't just for e-mails to sit around and take effect".

Conclusively
date: this game is indubitably worth playing. Play it. Seriously."

reviewText:
First things first:

This is NOT The Stanley Parable!
If you saw that this game was made by the same creator of The Stanley Parable, thinking you'll get another wild and absurd game like that one, DO NOT BUY THIS ONE.

The Beginner's Guide, instead, is actually a heartfelt and emotional trip through the works of a talented and bright abstract video game artist. Overfull with visual wonder, interpretation and pure creativity. The actual experience is not in the game itself but the backstory of the relationship between the narrator and a close friend who made originally made this collection of small games over the course of 2009-2011.
I won't say too much about it, since the experience is all in the history of these two people, but I will say that the collection of work is magnificent, some of the most visually stunning abstract video game art I've seen.
But just like The Stanley Parable, The Beginner's Guide does not follow the rules of video games and instead sets out to make it's own experience without pandering to a mainstream crowd.

With that said, this game is not meant for average gamers. There are no objectives or anything of the sort to be had, it's just a tribute to a friend. Which is I think the main downpoint, if you're making this for a friend, why are you charging $10? For a total length of an hour and a half, I can't see any justification. It's not like a museum gallery with a hefty entrance fee, it's a tribute.

Well, I don't have all the facts. So I'll just say this: If you're interested in video games as an art form, a means of expression or just a creative outlet, then The Beginner's Guide would probably be right up your alley. Otherwise, you'd be best off moving along.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This is one of the most incredible games I have ever played. Bioshock Infinite was amazing, but this takes the cake by a mile. This game follows a narrative (stay with me, I understand, thats strange for a game, but keep reading) in which we see a man trying to explain to us a person that he knows through the creations he has made. At first it seemed a little strange, but it quickly grasped my interest and I was sucked in and couldnt stop playing it. When I play a game, I look for how I get attached to a character in it. Bioshock Infinite got me attached to Elizabeth, as a protector. An amazing way to do that considering the end of the game...no spoilers here :). This game does a similar thing. It brings emotion into what you are doing, in a meaning way that you enjoy. This game is by far, my favorite game of all time now. It is so good, so deep, so driven. I am unsure on exactly how to explain it. Its like a movie, and a story, mashed into a game. The way the game is done is just incredible, like a letter to a friend. Just play it, its worth it, completely and utterly worth it. Just open the door...and find the light at the end....

reviewText:
It's not every day that I have a work of art move me as much as this experience just did. In my personal opinion The Beginners Guide is an absolute masterpiece. It's a game that will stick in my mind and keep sucking me back to thinking about it time and time again.

First off, the story is fantastic. What makes the game so powerful is the fact that the narrative touches on so many emotionally powerful topics that get woven into a grander theme of depression. This game doesn't shy away from offering emotional introspection and even goes into ideas like loneliness,  self destructive tendencies, and even projecting one's emotions onto other people. In a way, I think it even touches on what it is like to suffer from hyper empathy". It's a crazy feel trip that hits all the right buttons to get you thinking about some pretty heavy stuff.

But what's more is the fact is the entire experience is just so lovingly intertwined with the narrative. There's many points where the game's simple mechanics just seem to connect with the emotions of the story and allow me to feel connected to the experience in a much more profound way. At times I could feel the frustration being conveyed through the story in the game through the mechanics
date: while other times the mechanics mirrored feelings of peace or relief. The game uses this act of mirroring the narrative with gameplay and sprinkles in some exceptional audio design to build an intense atmosphere that can honestly even be described as overwhelming at times. It almost seems as if the creators went out of their way to use the concept of "kinesthetic projection" to draw me further into the game.\n\nIn the end
recommended: I can't recommend this game enough. Something as outright breathtaking as The Beginner's Guide needs to be supported with as much love as the gaming community is able to give. I love this thing so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ much and I'm not going to forget it for a LONG time."

reviewText:
I've struggled with depression and social anxiety. I have issues putting my own work out there for people to see.

I was hoping it'd be like The Stanley Parable, with crazy antics thrown in. But...

Oh my God, I don't know what I was expecting.

The games themselves were interesting to see. I liked seeing incomplete games and weird formats. But it was the story that drove it home for me.

I can't begin to describe the emotions going through me as I played this game. The House game felt the most serene, and it made me feel at peace. But as I got further into the content, the content itself got more disturbing emotionally.

I'm sat here, thinking about the game, sobbing at a game for the first time in about two years.

After playing this with a friend for the first time for us both, it was interesting that by the end we found many parts where we read different things into what was going on. For both of us it was in a similar vein though.

reviewText:
Only took about 2 hours to beat but man... did it make me feels things. A game that is more like an interactive narrative where a narrator takes you through indie developed games created by a friend and then tells his perspective of what his friend was trying to convey in each one. I felt uneasy, depressed at times, and even concerned for the creator of the games, much like the narrator felt for his friend. By the end I felt I learned something about myself and others in a perspective that I never thought to take. Oddly enough, a GAME of all things made me see a different point of view about others and how they deal with seclusion and depression. Sometimes you don't need to be a fixer, sometimes you just need to shut up and listen.

Anyway, off the sappy bit. I highly recommend this game. An incredible narrative, sound effects that really drive the collection of games along, the atmosphere ranges from happy, to gloomy, and even sarcastic and pessimistic. Just an all around great game. 10/10

About the most honest, truthful, untrolly review I've given in a long time. That says a lot.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game becuase I adored Stanley Parable, and I figured that anything made by the guy who wrote such an amazing game had to be worth playing. After playing it the first time, I can say that my pre conceived notion wasn't wrong, it just wasn't true the way that I thought it would be.

This game made me feel emotions that a game has never made me feel. It is incredibly sobering and it completely sneaks up on you.

Yes, this game is absolutely worth playing. I won't tell you not to go into it expecting something similar to Stanley Parable, because that's exactly what I did and I did not find myself wishing the game to be anything other than what it was. If anything, The Stanley Parable is what gave me a reference point for being able to better understand this game. Both are games that force the player's thought process to transcend what they know of conventional video games, The Beginner's Guide is almost like looking at it from the other side.

I'm not sure if the creator meant this to be a side effect, but there were times that certain scenes in that game, and certain rooms I was in that felt like I had been there before in my actual life. This made it all the more emotionally jarring to play through, it gave me personal perspective on a game that is meant to be looking at it from someone else's perspective. In any case, it is truly a work of art, not becuase it is magnificient in any way, but because of the emotions it all but forces you to feel, even though it wasn't made for the players themselves.

I recommend that you play this game and try not to criticize how it made you feel about the people who made it or why, but that you criticize how it made you feel about yourself, if the game doesn't make you want to do that already.

reviewText: Why did I ask my friend to get me this for Christmas expecting something like the Stanley Parable, I don't know. But I got something unlike the Stanley Parable, I got the most emotional experience I have ever gotten in gaming. This game heavily impacted me, and I got a greater understanding of some people and what they go through. I haven't touched it since I completed the 2.5 hour gaming experience, and you might think that is a waste of money. No, it isn't. I want to keep it to support Davey. In fact, I don't feel that it is supporting Davey, I feel it is supporting Coda. I hope that one day Coda resumes his game creation, and he probably already has, but hasn't told Davey about it. If you get to the end, you'll know why. I hope, just hope, that Coda will see stuff like this not just from me, but from other people, and maybe he and Davey will get together again, and Coda will be more open. I recommend this game to anyone who wants a very deep experience and, most importantly, Coda.

reviewText:
8.5/10

Short review  Pros:
- I felt confused, intrigued, heart-warmed, entertained, lonely, depressed, betrayed, and pityful while playing. I practically felt everything
- Amazing atmosphere, you could honestly just take a screenshot during most of the gameplay and set it as a wallpaper.
Cons:
- Not really a game, more of a story, or an interactible movie.
- Leaves a mute/bitter taste in your mouth, and you will be feeling pretty depressed and empty through a majority of the game. Especially towards the end. (although that's probably intended)
- Some may think $10 (or $6 because of the sale) is a bit much for about 1.5 hours of story. I felt it was worth it.

Long Review This isn't a game. You don't shoot through hordes of aliens, or survive in an open world sandbox, or capture a flag, or build a city. It's a story. I'm afraid to elaborate on it, because every detail given away will detract from the experience, I highly recommend going in completely cold.

That being said, it's a rather emotionally daunting experience. This game made me feel so many different emotions I didn't know I could feel from simply pressing W, A, S, and D while listening to someone talk. I think this game story has elicited almost every emotion humanly possible out of me, in less than two hours of gameplay coupled with amazing atmosphere. The extent to which I felt those feelings? Not much, I mostly felt depressed and empty. I covered all 360 degrees of human emotion, but just barely.

From a completely objective point of view, is this worth $10 (or the $6 that I got it for on sale)? Eh. It depends. If you really want something to be entertained by, something to replay for hundreds (or even dozens) of hours, don't look here. Play TF2, or CSGO. This is just a captivating experience with a small paywall. I for one do not regret putting those $6 in for that feels trip"."

reviewText:
Wow. I think The Beginners Guide is something everyone should experience, and nearly everyone will experience differently. It was extremely powerful to me, I was sobbing into my keyboard at times, but some I know didn't really get it, and it didn't hit home with them like it did me. However no one I know flat out didn't enjoy it. they all took something away from it, just maybe differently than I did. The less you know about this game before you play it the better. But I rate this game a solid 8.5/10, if not a little higher.

You as the player will get to experience the entirety of Coda's work, a man who made many short games, with the guide of a narrator. You will uncover more and more about the creator, until there is nothing left. You very well may uncover some things about yourself you didn't know too.

Pros:

+Great narrator
+Good graphics that get better as you play
+Interesting story
+Well written
+Will punch you in the gut

Cons:

-Not quite as interactive as I hoped
-Will punch you in the gut
- May make you realize things about yourself you would've preferred not to
